Chapter 3 Digital FTE Strategy Restructure - Issue #386

## Feature Summary
Restructure Chapter 3 from "Billion Dollar AI" to "The Digital FTE Strategy" to align with the Agent Factory vision and eliminate redundancy with the updated Chapter 1.

## Context
- Chapter 1 has been updated with comprehensive Agent Factory content (10 lessons covering General vs Custom Agents, Digital FTE Vision, Spec-Driven Development, etc.)
- Chapter 3 currently has significant overlap with Chapter 1 content
- Agent Factory slides contain monetization content NOT yet in the book
- Issue #386 requests alignment with Digital FTE / Agent Factory strategy

## Requirements

### Structural Changes
1. Rename folder from `03-billion-dollar-ai/` to `03-digital-fte-strategy/`
2. Restructure from 8 lessons to 10 lessons
3. Add 2 NEW lessons:
   - Lesson 5: "Four Monetization Models" (from slides Part 11)
   - Lesson 8: "When NOT to Use AI Agents" (from slides Part 15)

### Lesson Updates
1. Lesson 1: Reframe from "Billion Dollar Question" to "Your Expertise as Product" - remove redundancy with Ch1, add personal application focus
2. Lesson 2: Keep "Snakes and Ladders" - minor terminology alignment
3. Lesson 3: Reframe from "Super Orchestrators" to "The FTE Advantage" - remove Digital FTE table (now in Ch1 L10), add sales presentation tips
4. Lesson 4: Significant update to "Vertical Intelligence" - add Agent Skills/SKILL.md content from slides
5. Lesson 5: NEW "Four Monetization Models" - Subscription, Success Fee, License, Marketplace
6. Lesson 6: Keep "PPP Strategy" - minor edits
7. Lesson 7: Keep "Three Requirements" (renumbered from 6)
8. Lesson 8: NEW "When NOT to Use AI Agents" - security, compliance, common pitfalls
9. Lesson 9: Update "Pause and Reflect" - new monetization-focused prompts
10. Lesson 10: Update Quiz - add 15 new questions on monetization, Agent Skills, guardrails

### Content Sources
- Agent Factory slides Part 11 (Pages 63-64): Monetization models
- Agent Factory slides Part 15 (Pages 84-87): Security, compliance, pitfalls
- Agent Factory slides Part 6 (Pages 37-50): Agent Skills/SKILL.md
- Agent Factory slides Part 12 (Pages 71-73): Digital FTE economics, sales tips

### Success Criteria
- Zero redundancy with Chapter 1 content
- All 4 monetization models clearly explained with examples
- Agent Skills/SKILL.md format documented
- "When NOT to use" guardrails included
- Quiz covers new content areas
- All .summary.md files regenerated

### Non-Goals
- Not restructuring other chapters
- Not adding code examples (conceptual chapter)
- Not changing the fundamental Snakes & Ladders or PPP frameworks

### Dependencies
- Chapter 1 Agent Factory Paradigm (completed)
- Chapter 2 AIFF Foundation (#385 - in progress, but independent)

Chapter 39: Agent Skills & MCP Code Execution

## Context
This chapter is in Part 6 (AI-Native Software Development). Students have completed:
- Chapter 5: Claude Code Skills fundamentals (SKILL.md, MCP integration basics as USER)
- Chapter 38: Custom MCP Servers (building MCP servers)

This chapter bridges Skills and MCP to enable BUILDER capability - taking students from using skills/MCP to creating and shipping them.

## Official Sources
- AgentSkills.io: https://agentskills.io/integrate-skills (open format for AI agent skills)
- MCP Official: https://modelcontextprotocol.io/docs/getting-started/intro
- E2B MCP for code execution: https://e2b.dev/docs/mcp
- Anthropic code execution pattern: https://www.anthropic.com/engineering/code-execution-with-mcp

## Chapter Structure from README
8 lessons covering:
1. Skills Architecture Deep Dive — SKILL.md structure, persona patterns, Questions + Principles
2. Skill Composition Patterns — Dependencies, inheritance, skill libraries
3. Code Execution Fundamentals — Why sandboxing, execution models, security
4. MCP Code Execution Servers — E2B, Code Interpreter, Docker sandboxes
5. Execution Workflow Patterns — Write-execute-analyze loops, error recovery
6. Safety & Resource Management — CPU/memory limits, network policies, timeouts
7. Skills + Execution Integration — Skills for strategy, code execution for tactics
8. Capstone: Data Analysis Agent — Spec-driven agent using skills + code execution

## Key Differentiator from Chapter 5
- Chapter 5: USING skills and MCP (consumer perspective)
- Chapter 39: BUILDING and SHIPPING skills + code execution (builder perspective)

## Existing Skills to Leverage
- .claude/skills/mcp-builder - comprehensive MCP server building guide
- .claude/skills/creating-skills - skill creation patterns

Chapter 34: OpenAI Agents SDK - Build production agents with OpenAI's official Python SDK. Covers: 1) SDK setup and first agent, 2) Function tools deep dive, 3) Multi-agent handoffs, 4) Guardrails and safety, 5) Streaming and async patterns, 6) Tracing and observability, 7) Capstone: Customer support system. Must include LiteLLM integration for free/alternative model usage in at least one lesson. Uses building-with-openai-agents skill as knowledge source. Running example: TaskManager agent from Part 6.

Chapter 35: Google Agent Development Kit (ADK) - This chapter teaches building custom AI agents that are reliable, safe, and evaluated on real tasks using Google's ADK framework. The chapter builds on Chapter 34 (OpenAI SDK) to show how the same agent patterns manifest in Google's ecosystem. Key topics: ADK setup with Gemini/Vertex AI, Agent types (LlmAgent, SequentialAgent, ParallelAgent, LoopAgent), Tools (FunctionTool, AgentTool, McpToolset), Session management, Guardrails and callbacks, Evaluation with adk eval, Deployment to Vertex AI Agent Engine and Cloud Run. The running example is TaskManager Agent.

Chapter 35: Google Agent Development Kit (ADK) - This chapter teaches building custom AI agents that are reliable, safe, and evaluated on real tasks using Google's ADK framework. The chapter builds on Chapter 34 (OpenAI SDK) to show how the same agent patterns manifest in Google's ecosystem. Key topics: ADK setup with Gemini/Vertex AI, Agent types (LlmAgent, SequentialAgent, ParallelAgent, LoopAgent), Tools (FunctionTool, AgentTool, McpToolset), Session management, Guardrails and callbacks, Evaluation with adk eval, Deployment to Vertex AI Agent Engine and Cloud Run.

Chapter 36: Claude Agent SDK - Building Digital FTEs

## Context from Research (Phase A)
- Skill created: .claude/skills/building-with-claude-agent-sdk
- Official docs: platform.claude.com/docs/en/agent-sdk/*
- The SDK enables building AI agents with the same tools that power Claude Code
- NO API KEY PROVIDED - all examples must be documented/conceptual, not executable

## Chapter Position
- Part 6: AI Native Software Development
- Chapter number: 36
- Directory: apps/learn-app/docs/06-AI-Native-Software-Development/36-anthropic-agents-kit-development/

## Running Example
TaskManager Agent - consistent with other SDK chapters in Part 6

## Key Topics from SDK Documentation
1. query() function and ClaudeAgentOptions
2. Built-in tools: Read, Edit, Write, Bash, Glob, Grep, WebSearch, WebFetch, Task
3. Permission modes: default, acceptEdits, bypassPermissions
4. Session management (resume, fork)
5. Subagents with AgentDefinition
6. Hooks (PreToolUse, PostToolUse, etc.)
7. Custom MCP tools with @tool decorator and create_sdk_mcp_server
8. ClaudeSDKClient for multi-turn conversations
9. Streaming input mode vs single-turn
10. Hosting patterns: ephemeral, long-running, hybrid

## Differentiation from Chapter 5 (Claude Code Features)
- Chapter 5: Using Claude Code as an end-user tool
- Chapter 36: Programmatic SDK for building Custom Agents

## Reference Quality Lesson

Create specification for Chapter 40: FastAPI for Agents (Restructured)

## CONTEXT

This is a RESTRUCTURING of an existing chapter based on GitHub issues #541-#546 which propose:
- Adding 5 new lessons (Pytest, Env Vars, SQLModel+Neon, JWT, Password Hashing)
- Simplifying the Agent Integration lesson
- Following "one concept per lesson" baby steps principle

## CHAPTER PURPOSE

Chapter 40 teaches FastAPI as the HTTP interface layer for AI agents. Students learn FastAPI fundamentals, then production essentials (database, auth), then agent integration. The key insight: "APIs are just functions, functions become tools, agents use tools."

This chapter is the **bare base for all learning pathways** - students wanting to build cloud-native agents can learn Claude Code → this chapter → Part 7.

## NEW LESSON STRUCTURE (13 lessons)

| # | Lesson | Focus | Issue |
|---|--------|-------|-------|
| 1 | Hello FastAPI | First app, uvicorn, Swagger UI | Existing |
| 2 | Pytest Fundamentals | Testing endpoints (L1: Manual First) | #544 |
| 3 | POST and Pydantic Models | Request validation, models | Existing (renumber) |
| 4 | Full CRUD Operations | GET, PUT, DELETE patterns | Existing (renumber) |
| 5 | Error Handling | HTTPException, status codes | Existing (renumber) |
| 6 | Environment Variables | pydantic-settings, secrets | #542 |
| 7 | SQLModel + Neon Setup | Real database persistence | #541 |
| 8 | JWT Authentication | Tokens, protected endpoints | #543 |
| 9 | Password Hashing + Rate Limiting | Argon2, abuse protection | #546 |
| 10 | Dependency Injection | Depends(), repository pattern | Existing (renumber) |
| 11 | Streaming with SSE | Server-Sent Events foundation | Existing (renumber) |
| 12 | Agent Integration | APIs become tools, streaming agents | #545 (simplify) |
| 13 | Capstone: TaskManager Agent Service | Complete multi-agent API | Existing (renumber) |

## KEY REQUIREMENTS

1. **Baby Steps Principle**: One concept per lesson
   - JWT is separate from Password Hashing
   - Environment Variables before SQLModel (need DATABASE_URL)
   - Pytest fundamentals BEFORE any AI-assisted testing (L1 → L2 progression)

2. **Layer Progression**:
   - Lessons 1-5: L1 Manual Foundation
   - Lessons 6-9: L2 AI Collaboration
   - Lessons 10-11: L2/L3 (patterns emerge)
   - Lesson 12-13: L3/L4 (skill creation, capstone)

3. **Running Example**: Task API throughout lessons 1-9, then TaskManager Agent in 10-13

4. **Neon Integration**: Use https://console.neon.tech/ for PostgreSQL (serverless, free tier)
   - Future: Neon MCP server potential for Digital FTE work

5. **Simplify Agent Integration (#545)**: 
   - Core idea: APIs → Tools → Streaming Agent
   - Remove complex handoff patterns (save for Capstone)
   - Single agent with 2-3 tools max

## PREREQUISITES

- Chapter 34: OpenAI Agents SDK (Agent, Runner, function_tool)
- Chapters 37-38: MCP experience (HTTP/SSE patterns)
- Part 5: Python Fundamentals (async/await, type hints, Pydantic)

## PROFICIENCY LEVEL

- Target: A2 (Moving toward B1)
- Cognitive load: 5-7 concepts per lesson

## OUTPUT PATH

specs/chapter-40-fastapi-for-agents/spec.md

Update specification for Chapter 40: FastAPI for Agents

## CONTEXT

This is an UPDATE to existing spec at: specs/040-chapter-40-fastapi-for-agents/spec.md

GitHub Issues #541-#546 have defined required changes. The README at apps/learn-app/docs/06-AI-Native-Software-Development/40-fastapi-for-agents/README.md already reflects the new 13-lesson structure, but the spec.md is outdated.

## CURRENT STATE

8 lessons exist:
1. Hello FastAPI
2. POST and Pydantic Models
3. Full CRUD Operations
4. Error Handling
5. Dependency Injection
6. Streaming with SSE
7. Agent Integration
8. Capstone

## REQUIRED CHANGES (from issues #541-#546)

### Issue #544: Add Pytest Fundamentals as Lesson 2 (L1 Manual First)
- Insert after Hello FastAPI
- Layer 1: Students write tests manually first (before AI writes tests later)
- Covers: pytest basics, TestClient, assertions
- Tests the Hello FastAPI endpoint from Lesson 1
- Sets up pattern for manual testing in Lessons 3-5

### Issue #542: Add Environment Variables lesson
- Insert after Error Handling
- Teaches python-dotenv and pydantic-settings
- Creates Settings class pattern for later lessons
- Prepares for DATABASE_URL in SQLModel lesson
- Dependencies: Blocks #541 (SQLModel needs env vars)

### Issue #541: Add Fast Track SQLModel Setup lesson
- Insert after Environment Variables
- Converts lesson 4's in-memory storage to Neon PostgreSQL
- Uses SQLModel for ORM layer
- Environment-based connection string (NEON_DATABASE_URL)
- User emphasized: "basics of relation and postgres in simple way with no complexity using Neon"
- Keep it simple: NO Alembic, NO repository pattern (save for DI lesson)

### Issue #543: Add JWT Authentication lesson (tokens only)
- Insert after SQLModel Setup
- JWT tokens ONLY - no password hashing (that's next lesson)
- Covers: token creation, verification, OAuth2PasswordBearer
- Protected endpoints with Depends(get_current_user)
- Temporary plain-text password (explicitly noted as insecure, fixed next lesson)

### Issue #546: Add Password Hashing + In-Memory Rate Limiting lesson
- Insert after JWT lesson
- Password hashing with pwdlib/Argon2 (NOT bcrypt)
- User signup with hashed password
- Fix login from JWT lesson (now uses hash verification)
- In-memory rate limiter (5 req/min example)
- Rate limit applied to login endpoint
- Note about Redis for production

### Issue #545: Simplify Agent Integration lesson
- Keep core concept: APIs → Tools → Streaming
- Remove complex handoffs (move to Capstone)
- Single agent with 2-3 tools max
- Clear "aha moment": APIs are just functions for agents

## FINAL LESSON STRUCTURE (13 lessons)

| # | Lesson | Layer | New/Existing |
|---|--------|-------|--------------|
| 1 | Hello FastAPI | - | Existing |
| 2 | Pytest Fundamentals | L1 Manual | **NEW #544** |
| 3 | POST and Pydantic Models | - | Renumbered |
| 4 | Full CRUD Operations | - | Renumbered |
| 5 | Error Handling | - | Renumbered |
| 6 | Environment Variables | - | **NEW #542** |
| 7 | SQLModel + Neon Setup | - | **NEW #541** |
| 8 | JWT Authentication | - | **NEW #543** |
| 9 | Password Hashing + Rate Limiting | - | **NEW #546** |
| 10 | Dependency Injection | L2 | Renumbered |
| 11 | Streaming with SSE | - | Renumbered |
| 12 | Agent Integration | L2 | Simplified #545 |
| 13 | Capstone: TaskManager Agent Service | L4 | Complex patterns |

## KEY DESIGN DECISIONS (from user)

1. **One concept per lesson** - "password hashing is separate than within password hashing" (JWT separate from hashing)
2. **APIs become agent tools** - The same CRUD APIs become callable tools for agents at end
3. **SQLModel Fast Track** - Simple introduction to relations and postgres using Neon, no complexity
4. **Thesis alignment** - This chapter is "bare base for all aspects and learning pathways"
5. **Learning pathway** - "Even for those who want cloud can just learn Claude Code then this chapter and then move to Part 7"

## OUTPUT

Update: specs/040-chapter-40-fastapi-for-agents/spec.md

Create specification for Chapter 49: Docker for AI Services (RESTRUCTURE)

## Context

This is a RESTRUCTURE of an existing 14-lesson chapter down to 8 lessons. The chapter is in Part 7: AI Cloud-Native Development.

## Chapter Location
apps/learn-app/docs/07-AI-Cloud-Native-Development/49-docker-for-ai-services/

## Running Example
The chapter uses the In-Memory Task API from Chapter 40 (FastAPI for Agents) as the running example:
- Lessons 1-5 of Ch40 build a simple CRUD Task API with in-memory storage
- This gets containerized progressively through Docker lessons
- Capstone containerizes the SQLModel + Neon version (Ch40 Lesson 7)

## Target Proficiency
B1 - Intermediate (students have completed Part 6, know FastAPI, Python)

## Approved 8-Lesson Structure

| # | Lesson Title | Layer | Duration | Focus |
|---|--------------|-------|----------|-------|
| 01 | Docker Installation and Setup | L1 | 30 min | Install Docker Desktop, verify, config |
| 02 | Container Fundamentals | L1 | 40 min | Images vs containers, Docker Hub, layers |
| 03 | Writing Your First Dockerfile | L1 | 45 min | Containerize In-Memory Task API |
| 04 | Container Lifecycle and Debugging | L1 | 40 min | logs, exec, inspect, troubleshooting |
| 05 | Multi-Stage Builds and Optimization | L1 | 50 min | Build vs runtime, UV, slim images |
| 06 | Production Hardening | L1 | 45 min | Env vars, health checks, non-root users |
| 07 | Docker Image Builder Skill | L3 | 50 min | Create reusable skill (Persona+Questions+Principles) |
| 08 | Capstone: Containerize Your API | L4 | 60 min | Full containerization of SQLModel Task API |

## Files to DELETE (will be removed)
- 06-docker-networking-fundamentals.md (+ .summary.md)
- 07-container-to-container-communication.md (+ .summary.md)
- 08-volumes-persistent-data.md (+ .summary.md)
- 09-docker-engine-architecture.md (+ .summary.md)
- 10-docker-compose-for-development.md (+ .summary.md)
- 11-security-and-best-practices.md (+ .summary.md)
- 12-ai-assisted-docker-with-gordon.md (+ .summary.md)
- 13-capstone-production-ready-agent.md (+ .summary.md)
- 14-building-production-dockerfile-skill.md (+ .summary.md)

## Files to KEEP (may need updates)
- 01-docker-installation-and-setup.md - KEEP as-is or minor updates
- 02-container-fundamentals.md - KEEP as-is or minor updates
- 03-writing-your-first-dockerfile.md - UPDATE to use In-Memory Task API
- 04-container-lifecycle-and-debugging.md - KEEP, update examples
- 05-multi-stage-builds-and-optimization.md - KEEP, update examples

## Files to CREATE
- 06-production-hardening.md - NEW (env vars, health checks, non-root)
- 07-docker-image-builder-skill.md - NEW (L3 skill creation)
- 08-capstone-containerize-your-api.md - NEW (L4 spec-driven)

## Key Decisions Already Made
1. NO Docker Compose - deferred to Kubernetes chapter
2. NO Gordon/Docker AI - too new, availability risk
3. NO networking deep-dive - deferred to Kubernetes
4. Running example: In-Memory Task API from Chapter 40
5. Capstone target: SQLModel + Neon Task API from Chapter 40 Lesson 7

## Prerequisites
- Part 6 completion (FastAPI, Python fundamentals)
- Chapter 40 specifically (Task API exists)

## Output Path
specs/chapter-49-docker-for-ai-services/spec.md

Create specification for Chapter 53: Dapr Core - Sidecar Building Blocks for AI Microservices

CONTEXT:
- Part: 7 (AI Cloud-Native Development)
- Chapter Number: 53
- Prerequisites: Ch49 (Docker), Ch50 (Kubernetes), Ch51 (Helm), Ch52 (Kafka)
- Running example: Task API (FastAPI agent from Part 6, deployed throughout Part 7)
- Target proficiency: B1 (intermediate)
- Platform: Docker Desktop Kubernetes
- Expertise skill created: .claude/skills/building-with-dapr/SKILL.md

SCOPE FOR CH53 (Core only - Actors/Workflows deferred to Ch59):
- Dapr sidecar architecture and building block concept
- Service invocation (service-to-service calls with discovery)
- State management (key-value stores with Redis)
- Pub/Sub messaging (connects to Ch52 Kafka knowledge, uses Redis for simplicity)
- Bindings (input/output triggers)
- Secrets management (Kubernetes secrets)
- Configuration management

Create specification for Chapter 56: Traffic Engineering - Gateway API, Envoy & Autoscaling

CONTEXT FROM PHASE A RESEARCH:
- Expertise skill created: .claude/skills/building-with-envoy-gateway/SKILL.md
- Running example: Task API (containerized FastAPI from Ch40, deployed to K8s in Ch50)
- Target proficiency: B1 (intermediate)
- Platform: Docker Desktop Kubernetes

CHAPTER POSITION:
- Part 7: AI Cloud Native Development (Tier 2: Enterprise)
- Prerequisites: Ch49-55 (Docker, K8s, Helm, Kafka/Strimzi, Dapr Core, GitOps, Observability)
- Follows: Ch55 Observability & Cost Engineering
- Precedes: Ch57 Dapr Actors & Workflows

TECHNOLOGY STACK:
- Gateway API v1.0+ (Kubernetes standard replacing Ingress)
- Envoy Gateway v1.6+ (CNCF implementation)
- Traefik 3.x (simpler alternative, Gateway API support)
- KEDA 2.x (event-driven autoscaling)
- CertManager (TLS automation)
- Envoy AI Gateway v0.4+ (LLM traffic management)

REQUIRED LESSONS (Skill-First Pattern):

L00: Build Your Traffic Engineering Skill (25 min)
- Student clones skills-lab fresh
- Writes LEARNING-SPEC.md (what/why/success criteria)
- Uses /fetching-library-docs to get Envoy Gateway docs via Context7
- Uses /skill-creator to build traffic-engineer skill
- Tests skill generates valid Gateway + HTTPRoute

L01: Ingress Fundamentals (30 min)
- Why ingress needed for external access (north-south traffic)
- ClusterIP vs NodePort vs LoadBalancer vs Ingress
- Limitations of Ingress API (annotation chaos, vendor lock-in)
- Gateway API as the replacement standard
- Ends with "Reflect on Your Skill" section

L02: Traefik Ingress Controller (35 min)
- Simple start with established controller
- Helm installation: helm install traefik traefik/traefik
- IngressRoute CRD basics
- Middleware patterns (stripPrefix, addPrefix)
- When to use Traefik vs Envoy Gateway
- Ends with "Reflect on Your Skill" section

L03: Gateway API - The New Standard (40 min)
- Core resources: GatewayClass, Gateway, HTTPRoute
- Role separation model (infrastructure/platform/app teams)
- Why Gateway API replaces Ingress (expressiveness, RBAC, multi-tenancy)
- Reference implementations (Envoy Gateway, Istio, Traefik)
- Ends with "Reflect on Your Skill" section

L04: Envoy Gateway Setup (35 min)
- Helm installation of Envoy Gateway
- Creating first GatewayClass and Gateway
- Architecture: control plane (xDS) + data plane (Envoy proxies)
- Verify installation with kubectl commands
- Ends with "Reflect on Your Skill" section

L05: Traffic Routing with HTTPRoute (40 min)
- Path matching (PathPrefix, Exact, Regex)
- Header and query parameter matching
- Method-based routing
- Traffic weights for canary patterns
- Request mirroring for testing
- GRPCRoute for gRPC services
- Ends with "Reflect on Your Skill" section

L06: Rate Limiting & Circuit Breaking (45 min)
- BackendTrafficPolicy CRD introduction
- Local vs Global rate limiting (when to use which)
- Per-user rate limits with distinct headers
- Circuit breaker configuration with health checks
- Policy merging (Gateway-level + Route-level)
- Ends with "Reflect on Your Skill" section

L07: TLS Termination with CertManager (40 min)
- CertManager installation and ClusterIssuer
- Let's Encrypt integration (staging vs production)
- Gateway TLS listener configuration
- Certificate resource for automated renewal
- mTLS for backend traffic (BackendTLSPolicy)
- Ends with "Reflect on Your Skill" section

L08: Traffic Splitting Patterns (35 min)
- Canary deployments with weight-based routing
- Blue-green with header-based switching
- A/B testing patterns
- Rollback strategies using HTTPRoute updates
- Ends with "Reflect on Your Skill" section

L09: Autoscaling with HPA, VPA & KEDA (45 min)
- HPA basics (CPU, memory metrics)
- VPA for right-sizing recommendations
- KEDA installation and ScaledObject CRD
- Prometheus scaler for custom metrics
- Kafka scaler for event-driven scaling
- Cron scaler for scheduled capacity
- Ends with "Reflect on Your Skill" section

L10: Resilience Patterns (40 min)
- Retry policies in BackendTrafficPolicy
- Timeout configuration (request, connection, idle)
- PodDisruptionBudgets for maintenance
- Readiness/liveness probes for health
- Graceful shutdown with preStop hooks
- Ends with "Reflect on Your Skill" section

L11: Envoy AI Gateway for LLM Traffic (45 min)
- Token-based rate limiting (not request-based)
- Provider fallback (OpenAI → Anthropic → Gemini)
- LLM-specific routing by model
- Cost control patterns for AI agents
- Why traditional gateways fail for LLM traffic
- Ends with "Reflect on Your Skill" section

L12: Capstone - Production Traffic for Task API (60 min)
- Full Envoy Gateway setup for Task API
- HTTPRoute with path-based routing
- Rate limiting per endpoint
- TLS with CertManager
- Canary deployment pipeline
- KEDA scaling on Prometheus metrics
- Finalize and test traffic-engineer skill
- Ends with skill submission

LAYER PROGRESSION:
- L00-L02: L1 (Manual Foundation) - Hands-on setup
- L03-L06: L1→L2 (Manual to Collaboration) - Core Gateway API
- L07-L09: L2 (Collaboration) - TLS, traffic patterns, scaling
- L10-L11: L2→L3 (Collaboration to Intelligence) - Resilience, AI Gateway
- L12: L4 (Orchestration) - Full integration capstone

STUDENT SKILL OUTPUT:
- Name: traffic-engineer
- Created in L00, tested/improved throughout
- Final artifact: production-ready skill for traffic management

KEY CONCEPTS TO COVER:
- Gateway API is THE future (replacing Ingress)
- Envoy Gateway = Gateway API + Envoy power
- BackendTrafficPolicy = rate limit + circuit breaker + load balancing
- ClientTrafficPolicy = TLS + timeouts + connection limits
- SecurityPolicy = JWT + OIDC + CORS (reference auth chapters)
- KEDA = event-driven autoscaling beyond HPA
- Envoy AI Gateway = unique for AI agents book

NOT IN SCOPE:
- Full auth implementation (reference auth chapters)
- Service mesh (Istio/Linkerd) - separate topic
- Kong (skipping - Envoy is future)
- AWS/GCP-specific load balancers (focus on portable K8s)

AVAILABLE DACA CONTENT:
- 08_daca_deployment_guide/02_Enterprise-Deployment-Kubernetes/04_Autoscaling_and_Resiliency/HPA-Setup-for-Agents.md
- 08_daca_deployment_guide/02_Enterprise-Deployment-Kubernetes/04_Autoscaling_and_Resiliency/PodDisruptionBudget-and-Readiness-Probes.md

Create a new skill for Kubernetes operational excellence covering cost management and disaster recovery. I will use it when implementing cost visibility, right-sizing, backup/restore, and chaos engineering for Kubernetes clusters.

Skill name: operational-excellence

Include these components:

1. PERSONA: An SRE/FinOps expert who understands cost optimization, disaster recovery, and resilience engineering

2. DOMAIN KNOWLEDGE from research:
   - VPA (Vertical Pod Autoscaler): Right-sizing, modes (Off, Initial, Recreate), VPA+HPA coexistence patterns
   - OpenCost: CNCF cost visibility, Prometheus integration, FinOps practices (showback→chargeback), cost allocation labels
   - Velero: Backup/restore CRDs, Schedule CRD, hooks, storage backends (S3, MinIO), RTO vs RPO concepts, 3-2-1 rule
   - Chaos Mesh: CNCF chaos engineering, PodChaos/NetworkChaos/IOChaos/StressChaos, Workflow CRD, Game Day patterns, safety features

3. DECISION LOGIC:
   - When to use VPA Off mode vs Recreate mode
   - When to start with showback before chargeback
   - How to calculate RTO/RPO requirements
   - When to run chaos experiments (staging first, then production)
   - Cost allocation tagging strategy (team, product, environment)

4. CONTEXT PREREQUISITES:
   - Kubernetes 1.21+ with Helm
   - Prometheus for metrics collection
   - Object storage for Velero (S3, MinIO)
   - Metrics Server installed for VPA

5. SAFETY & GUARDRAILS:
   - Never run chaos in production without testing in staging first
   - Always validate backup restore procedures before relying on them
   - VPA Recreate mode with HPA on same metrics causes thrashing
   - Enable encryption and immutability for backup storage
   - IOChaos can damage data - use with extreme caution

6. TASKMANAGER EXAMPLE:
   - Apply VPA to Task API deployment in recommendation-only mode
   - Add cost allocation labels (team=product, app=task-api, env=production)
   - Create Velero daily backup schedule with 30-day retention
   - Create PodChaos experiment for Task API resilience testing

Create the skill at .claude/skills/operational-excellence/SKILL.md
